path_1.title: Whiplash (2013)
path_1.feeling: Absolutely electric

path_1.title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)
path_1.feeling: Fun, nostalgic space romp that hits the adventure sweet spot.

path_1.title: Apollo 13 (1995)
path_1.feeling: Gripping, inspiring procedural that had me holding my breath.

path_1.title: The Angry Birds Movie (2016)
path_1.feeling: Glossy but empty

path_1.title: Angels in the Outfield (1994)
path_1.feeling: Sweet and harmless, but a bit too syrupy for me.

path_1.title: Hudsucker Proxy, The (1994)
path_1.feeling: Buoyant Coen whimsy with style to spare, if a touch overlong.

path_1.title: Reservoir Dogs (1992)
path_1.feeling: Taut, sharp, and nasty in all the right ways.

path_1.title: When We Were Kings (1996)
path_1.feeling: Rousing, soulful sports doc that gave me chills.

path_1.title: Good Will Hunting (1997)
path_1.feeling: Earnest and affecting, even if a bit tidy.

path_1.title: Dracula (Bram Stoker's Dracula) (1992)
path_1.feeling: Lavish and moody, but the romance didn’t fully land.

path_1.title: Alien (1979)
path_1.feeling: Perfect slow-burn terror that still feels unbeatable.

path_1.title: Rear Window (1954)
path_1.feeling: Clever setup and engaging, though it kept me at a slight distance.

path_1.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_1.feeling: Ambitious and moving

path_1.title: Spotlight (2015)
path_1.feeling: Riveting, meticulous, and deeply humane.

path_1.title: Shrek the Third (2007)
path_1.feeling: Tired gags and franchise fatigue set in fast.

path_1.title: Craft, The (1996)
path_1.feeling: Stylish teen goth vibes with uneven bite.

path_1.title: Sixth Sense, The (1999)
path_1.feeling: Quietly haunting and emotionally satisfying.

path_1.title: Mission: Impossible (1996)
path_1.feeling: Slick espionage thrills with standout set pieces.

path_1.title: Gone Girl (2014)
path_1.feeling: Cold, twisty fun with a mean streak I enjoyed.

path_1.title: Network (1976)
path_1.feeling: Scathing and prophetic

path_1.title: Rushmore (1998)
path_1.feeling: Wry, heartfelt, and perfectly off-kilter—loved it.

path_1.title: True Romance (1993)
path_1.feeling: Violent, pulpy rush with a weirdly sweet core.

path_1.title: Hercules (1997)
path_1.feeling: Zippy tunes and Hades steal the show, even if it’s lightweight.

path_1.title: Antz (1998)
path_1.feeling: Witty and odd, but the charm comes in spurts.

path_1.title: Dirty Grandpa (2016)
path_1.feeling: Crass without the clever

path_1.title: Iron Man (2008)
path_1.feeling: Charismatic, breezy kick-off that still flies.

path_1.title: Die Hard 2 (1990)
path_1.feeling: Solid holiday carnage, just not as sharp as the original.

path_1.title: Godfather, The (1972)
path_1.feeling: Majestic, absorbing crime saga—flawless.

path_1.title: Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back (2001)
path_1.feeling: Juvenile goofs that hit occasionally, miss often.

path_1.title: Fifth Element, The (1997)
path_1.feeling: Inventive, colorful sci-fi joyride with loads of personality.

path_2.title: Whiplash (2013)
path_2.feeling: A white-knuckle duel of obsession that left me buzzing and breathless.

path_2.title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)
path_2.feeling: A lively nostalgia play—fun, but too derivative to truly soar.

path_2.title: Apollo 13 (1995)
path_2.feeling: Taut, inspiring space procedural that had me gripping the armrests.

path_2.title: The Angry Birds Movie (2016)
path_2.feeling: A noisy brand extension with a few stray laughs and not much else.

path_2.title: Angels in the Outfield (1994)
path_2.feeling: Sweet and sappy comfort food that works in modest doses.

path_2.title: Hudsucker Proxy, The (1994)
path_2.feeling: Sumptuous screwball clockwork—charming, if a bit airless.

path_2.title: Reservoir Dogs (1992)
path_2.feeling: Lean, nasty, and crackling with attitude—I was glued.

path_2.title: When We Were Kings (1996)
path_2.feeling: Exhilarating, soulful portrait of Ali and a moment in history.

path_2.title: Good Will Hunting (1997)
path_2.feeling: Sincere, well-acted uplift that hit me more than it should.

path_2.title: Dracula (Bram Stoker's Dracula) (1992)
path_2.feeling: Lush, operatic excess—gorgeous to look at, dramatically uneven.

path_2.title: Alien (1979)
path_2.feeling: Suffocating dread distilled to perfection

path_2.title: Rear Window (1954)
path_2.feeling: Immaculate craftsmanship that I admired more than I loved.

path_2.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_2.feeling: Grand, heartfelt sci-fi that stirred me even when it strained.

path_2.title: Spotlight (2015)
path_2.feeling: Sober, riveting journalism with moral clarity that floored me.

path_2.title: Shrek the Third (2007)
path_2.feeling: Tired gags and franchise fatigue—mostly a slog.

path_2.title: Craft, The (1996)
path_2.feeling: Stylish teen witchery with attitude, compelling but uneven.

path_2.title: Sixth Sense, The (1999)
path_2.feeling: Quietly haunting and tender, with a payoff that devastates.

path_2.title: Mission: Impossible (1996)
path_2.feeling: Sleek spy thrills and bravura set pieces—purely satisfying.

path_2.title: Gone Girl (2014)
path_2.feeling: A dark, twisty marital mind game with razor-sharp bite.

path_2.title: Network (1976)
path_2.feeling: Scathing, prophetic media satire that still crackles.

path_2.title: Rushmore (1998)
path_2.feeling: Bittersweet, meticulously whimsical, and sneakily moving.

path_2.title: True Romance (1993)
path_2.feeling: Neon pulp romance—violent, funny, and unexpectedly sweet.

path_2.title: Hercules (1997)
path_2.feeling: Breezy, catchy Disney romp that goes down easy.

path_2.title: Antz (1998)
path_2.feeling: Neurotic wit and sharp voice work propping up a thin tale.

path_2.title: Dirty Grandpa (2016)
path_2.feeling: Crass, lazy shock humor with vanishingly few laughs.

path_2.title: Iron Man (2008)
path_2.feeling: Breezy charisma and clean action—an effortlessly fun launch.

path_2.title: Die Hard 2 (1990)
path_2.feeling: Snowbound mayhem that’s overstuffed but entertaining.

path_2.title: Godfather, The (1972)
path_2.feeling: Majestic, operatic crime saga that swept me away.

path_2.title: Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back (2001)
path_2.feeling: Scattershot in-jokes—some hits, plenty of misses.

path_2.title: Fifth Element, The (1997)
path_2.feeling: Giddy, candy-colored space opera with irresistible energy.

path_2.title: Whiplash (2013)
path_2.feeling: A gut-punch of obsession that left me rattled and exhilarated.

path_2.title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)
path_2.feeling: Fun nostalgia play with energy, but too safe to really floor me.

path_2.title: Apollo 13 (1995)
path_2.feeling: Taut, inspiring procedural that had me locked in start to finish.

path_2.title: The Angry Birds Movie (2016)
path_2.feeling: Loud, plastic, and lifeless—more brand than movie.

path_2.title: Angels in the Outfield (1994)
path_2.feeling: Sweet but syrupy

path_2.feeling: Whimsical Coen screwball clockwork that charmed me more than it moved me.

path_2.feeling: Tense, razor-edged crime chamber piece crackling with vicious wit.

path_2.feeling: Electric, soulful documentary that hums with history and swagger.

path_2.title: Good Will Hunting (1997)
path_2.feeling: Earnest and affecting, if a bit neat around the edges.

path_2.feeling: Sumptuous and feverish, but the melodrama dulls the bite.

path_2.title: Rear Window (1954)
path_2.feeling: Clever and precise, though it kept me at a cool distance.

path_2.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_2.feeling: Awe-struck, ambitious sci-fi with real heart and thunder.

path_2.title: Spotlight (2015)
path_2.feeling: Riveting, humane journalism that hits with quiet, devastating force.

path_2.title: Shrek the Third (2007)
path_2.feeling: Jokey filler with no spark—franchise fumes.

path_2.feeling: Stylish teen witchcraft with attitude, fun but thin.

path_2.title: Sixth Sense, The (1999)
path_2.feeling: Quietly haunting and tender with a killer final shiver.

path_2.title: Mission: Impossible (1996)
path_2.feeling: Slick, twisty espionage thrills with De Palma flair.

path_2.title: Gone Girl (2014)
path_2.feeling: Icy, razor-sharp mind game that twists the knife with wicked precision.

path_2.title: Network (1976)
path_2.feeling: Savage, prophetic satire that still crackles and stings.

path_2.title: Rushmore (1998)
path_2.feeling: Wry, tender coming-of-age brimming with handmade charm.

path_2.title: True Romance (1993)
path_2.feeling: Violent, candy-colored pulp with messy heart and propulsive swagger.

path_2.title: Hercules (1997)
path_2.feeling: Zippy tunes and jokey myth make for breezy, if slight, fun.

path_2.title: Antz (1998)
path_2.feeling: Snarky, clever early CG that amuses more than it amazes.

path_2.title: Dirty Grandpa (2016)
path_2.feeling: Grody, try-hard raunch that left me wincing more than laughing.

path_2.feeling: Effortless pop-blockbuster charm with a gleaming engine.

path_2.feeling: Solid, snowy mayhem that can’t match the original’s spark.

path_2.feeling: Operatic, inexorable tragedy—criminal mythmaking at its finest.

path_2.title: Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back (2001)
path_2.feeling: Goofy self-referential lark with more smirk than bite.

path_2.feeling: Day-glo space opera that’s exuberant, weird, and a blast.

path_2.title: Whiplash (2013)
path_2.feeling: White-knuckle obsession and abuse played like a drum solo to the throat

path_2.feeling: Fun, polished nostalgia that hums along but rarely surprises me

path_2.title: Apollo 13 (1995)
path_2.feeling: Rousing, detail-rich crisis management that had me clenched and inspired

path_2.title: The Angry Birds Movie (2016)
path_2.feeling: Plastic, cynical IP filler that slid off my brain mid-viewing

path_2.title: Angels in the Outfield (1994)
path_2.feeling: Sweet but syrupy wish-fulfillment that left me mostly unmoved

path_2.feeling: Goofy, clockwork Coens—gorgeous artifice with a slightly hollow center

path_2.title: Reservoir Dogs (1992)
path_2.feeling: Lean, nasty debut crackling with tension and razor-wire dialogue

path_2.feeling: Electrifying portrait of myth, politics, and showmanship that still gives me chills

path_2.feeling: Sumptuous goth romance that’s more mood than menace for me

path_2.title: Rear Window (1954)
path_2.feeling: Ingenious and elegant, though its icy remove keeps me a step outside

path_2.title: Spotlight (2015)
path_2.feeling: Rigorous, humane journalism that had me riveted and quietly wrecked

path_2.feeling: Shrill, mechanical franchise fumes with little wit left in the tank

path_2.feeling: Teen witchery with attitude to spare but thin scares and thinner stakes

path_2.feeling: Elegantly eerie and tender, its twist lands because the emotions do

path_2.title: Gone Girl (2014)
path_2.feeling: Icy, venomous fun—each reveal tightened the knife

path_2.feeling: Savage, prophetic media satire that still feels uncomfortably current

path_2.title: Rushmore (1998)
path_2.feeling: Deadpan, bittersweet delight with immaculate Wes rhythms

path_2.feeling: Candy-colored pulp that charms even as the macho swagger grates a bit

path_2.feeling: Breezy, jokey Disney with catchy tunes and harmless fluff

path_2.title: Antz (1998)
path_2.feeling: Neurotic, witty romp that entertains more than it resonates

path_2.feeling: Effortless origin-story charm powered by sheer star wattage

path_2.feeling: Snowy, loud retread that still scratches the action itch

path_2.feeling: Fun, polished nostalgia hit with energy, if a bit too safe to truly thrill.

path_2.feeling: Riveting, work‑the‑problem procedural that had me white‑knuckled and moved.

path_2.title: The Angry Birds Movie (2016)

path_2.feeling: Sweet‑hearted schmaltz that goes down easy but left me unmoved.

path_2.feeling: Zippy, ornate Coen screwball—big‑hearted and gleefully stylized.

path_2.title: Reservoir Dogs (1992)
path_2.feeling: Lean, vicious chamber piece crackling with menace and swagger.

path_2.title: Good Will Hunting (1997)

path_2.feeling: Sleek, twisty espionage puzzle with cool, controlled thrills.

path_2.title: Gone Girl (2014)

path_2.feeling: Candy‑coated carnage—fun, if a bit adolescent around the edges.

path_2.feeling: Competent, snowy rerun thrills—fun, if nowhere near the peak.

path_2.feeling: Juvenile, self‑referential romp with scattered chuckles.

path_2.title: Fifth Element, The (1997)
path_2.feeling: Bold, candy‑colored sci‑fi goof that won me over with sheer style.

path_3.title: Whiplash (2013)
path_3.feeling: White-knuckle intensity and bruising ambition left me breathless.

path_3.feeling: Fun nostalgia with brisk thrills, but too safe to truly soar.

path_3.feeling: Tense, compassionate procedural heroism that still rouses.

path_3.title: The Angry Birds Movie (2016)
path_3.feeling: Glossy, noisy IP fluff that left me cold.

path_3.feeling: Sweet-natured schmaltz that lands a few warm-hearted hits.

path_5.title: When We Were Kings (1996)
path_5.feeling: A rousing, soulful chronicle that gave me chills.

path_5.title: Good Will Hunting (1997)
path_5.feeling: Earnest, well-acted catharsis that worked despite the gloss.

path_5.title: Dracula (Bram Stoker's Dracula) (1992)
path_5.feeling: Lush, operatic romance-horror whose style outpaces its heart.

path_5.title: Alien (1979)
path_5.feeling: Pristine terror and atmosphere—space-horror perfection.

path_5.title: Rear Window (1954)
path_5.feeling: Ingenious, coolly crafted suspense that I admire more than love.

path_5.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_5.feeling: Big-hearted cosmic awe that swept me up, flaws and all.

path_5.title: Spotlight (2015)
path_5.feeling: Riveting, quietly devastating procedural with moral weight.

path_5.title: Shrek the Third (2007)
path_5.feeling: Shrug-worthy hijinks—slick but charmless franchise fumes.

path_5.title: Craft, The (1996)
path_5.feeling: Moody teen occult melodrama that casts an uneven spell.

path_5.title: Sixth Sense, The (1999)
path_5.feeling: Elegant, empathetic ghost story that still lands emotionally.

path_5.title: Mission: Impossible (1996)
path_5.feeling: Clean, twisty spy thrills with sleek, satisfying set pieces.

path_5.title: Gone Girl (2014)
path_5.feeling: Icy, sharp-edged media nightmare that kept me leaning forward.

path_5.title: Network (1976)
path_5.feeling: Savage, still-razor satire that bites hard and lingers.

path_5.title: Rushmore (1998)
path_5.feeling: Tender, offbeat ambition and melancholy in perfect balance.

path_5.title: True Romance (1993)
path_5.feeling: Pulpy, affectionate mayhem with genuine sparks between the leads.

path_5.title: Hercules (1997)
path_5.feeling: Breezy, quippy myth remix—fun if lightweight.

path_5.title: Antz (1998)
path_5.feeling: Wry, neurotic toon with bite, though its world feels cramped.

path_5.title: Dirty Grandpa (2016)
path_5.feeling: Crass, scattershot gags with a low hit rate.

path_5.title: Iron Man (2008)
path_5.feeling: Effortless charm and clean origin-story propulsion.

path_5.title: Die Hard 2 (1990)
path_5.feeling: Wintry, overcranked sequel that still delivers solid thrills.

path_5.title: Godfather, The (1972)
path_5.feeling: Operatic, inexorable tragedy—flawless craft and moral gravity.

path_5.title: Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back (2001)
path_5.feeling: Juvenile, self-referential goofs that amuse in bursts.

path_5.title: Fifth Element, The (1997)
path_5.feeling: Dayglo space opera—goofy, inventive, and irresistibly fun.

path_5.title: Whiplash (2013)
path_5.feeling: Absolutely electrified me—precision, obsession, and bruising mentorship at full blast.

path_5.title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)
path_5.feeling: Fun return to form that echoes a bit too loudly, but the energy carries it.

path_5.title: Apollo 13 (1995)
path_5.feeling: Gripping, clear-eyed heroism that had me clenching despite knowing the outcome.

path_5.title: The Angry Birds Movie (2016)
path_5.feeling: Bright, noisy IP sugar rush that left little to savor.

path_5.title: Angels in the Outfield (1994)
path_5.feeling: Sweet, faith-and-baseball comfort food, a touch too syrupy.

path_5.title: Hudsucker Proxy, The (1994)
path_5.feeling: Clockwork whimsy and snap—stylish, charming, a minor delight.

path_5.title: Reservoir Dogs (1992)
path_5.feeling: Tense, talky bloodbath with razor banter and pulsing dread.

path_5.title: When We Were Kings (1996)
path_5.feeling: Thrilling, soulful portrait of Ali and a moment that still reverberates.

path_5.title: Good Will Hunting (1997)
path_5.feeling: Earnest therapy-and-genius drama that hit the heart even when it telegraphed.

path_5.title: Dracula (Bram Stoker's Dracula) (1992)
path_5.feeling: Gothic flourish over feeling—sumptuous, uneven, intermittently hypnotic.

path_5.title: Alien (1979)
path_5.feeling: Pure atmosphere and terror—a perfect machine of dread.

path_5.title: Rear Window (1954)
path_5.feeling: Clever, impeccably staged voyeurism that I admire more than I love.

path_5.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_5.feeling: Big, soaring sci-fi that moved me even through its rough edges.

path_5.title: Spotlight (2015)
path_5.feeling: Methodical, humane journalism that shook me to the core.

path_5.title: Shrek the Third (2007)
path_5.feeling: Tired throne gags and franchise fumes—thin laughs, thinner heart.

path_5.title: Craft, The (1996)
path_5.feeling: Stylish teen witchcraft with bite, more vibe than depth.

path_5.title: Sixth Sense, The (1999)
path_5.feeling: Quietly haunting, well-tuned ghost story that still lands.

path_5.title: Mission: Impossible (1996)
path_5.feeling: Sleek, twisty spy fun with set pieces that still pop.

path_5.title: Gone Girl (2014)
path_5.feeling: Icy, razor-edged media marriage war that kept me hooked.

path_5.title: Network (1976)
path_5.feeling: Savage, prophetic media satire that still crackles.

path_5.title: Rushmore (1998)
path_5.feeling: Precise, melancholy whimsy—deadpan laughs with an aching core.

path_5.title: True Romance (1993)
path_5.feeling: Pulp romance and gunpowder—messy, gripping, and fun.

path_5.title: Hercules (1997)
path_5.feeling: Zippy songs and a scene-stealing Hades—light, likable Disney.

path_5.title: Antz (1998)
path_5.feeling: Neurotic, witty bug satire whose charm outpaces its dated sheen.

path_5.title: Dirty Grandpa (2016)
path_5.feeling: Strained raunch with scattered laughs and a lot of groan.

path_5.title: Iron Man (2008)
path_5.feeling: Snappy origin with star wattage—sleek and satisfying.

path_5.title: Die Hard 2 (1990)
path_5.feeling: Snowy, overcaffeinated rerun that still delivers sturdy thrills.

path_5.title: Godfather, The (1972)
path_5.feeling: Operatic crime family saga—immaculate, absorbing, inevitable.

path_5.title: Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back (2001)
path_5.feeling: Juvenile, self-referential romp with enough gags to coast.

path_5.title: Fifth Element, The (1997)
path_5.feeling: Candy-colored sci-fi exuberance—goofy, stylish, and a blast.

path_5.title: Whiplash (2013)
path_5.feeling: A ferocious, nerve-frying duel that left me wired and exhilarated.

path_5.title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)
path_5.feeling: A zippy, crowd-pleasing revival that thrills even as it color-copies.

path_5.title: Apollo 13 (1995)
path_5.feeling: A gripping, nuts-and-bolts rescue saga that hit my procedural sweet spot.

path_5.title: The Angry Birds Movie (2016)
path_5.feeling: Bright and busy, but mostly a hollow sugar rush.

path_5.title: Angels in the Outfield (1994)
path_5.feeling: Sweet, earnest fantasy whose syrup goes down easier than it sticks.

path_5.title: Hudsucker Proxy, The (1994)
path_5.feeling: Whimsical, clockwork Coens—style-forward, but I happily rode the gears.

path_5.title: Reservoir Dogs (1992)
path_5.feeling: Lean, nasty, and crackling—crime under pressure that grips hard.

path_5.title: When We Were Kings (1996)
path_5.feeling: Electrifying portrait of Ali, politics, and spectacle that still pumps the blood.

path_5.title: Good Will Hunting (1997)
path_5.feeling: Sincere, well-acted catharsis that works despite familiar beats.

path_5.title: Dracula (Bram Stoker's Dracula) (1992)
path_5.feeling: Sumptuous Gothic romance whose melodrama kept me at arm’s length.

path_5.title: Alien (1979)
path_5.feeling: A perfect slow-burn nightmare that still crawls under my skin.

path_5.title: Rear Window (1954)
path_5.feeling: Ingeniously staged voyeurism that left me admiring more than absorbed.

path_5.title: Interstellar (2014)
path_5.feeling: Audacious, heartfelt sci-fi whose ambition and emotion carried me.

path_5.title: Spotlight (2015)
path_5.feeling: Precise, humane journalism thriller that gripped me start to finish.

path_5.title: Shrek the Third (2007)
path_5.feeling: A thin, jokey retread that made me miss the swamp’s spark.

path_5.title: Craft, The (1996)
path_5.feeling: Stylish teen witchery with bite—more mood than menace.

path_5.title: Sixth Sense, The (1999)
path_5.feeling: An elegant, melancholy ghost story whose craft and payoff landed.

path_5.title: Mission: Impossible (1996)
path_5.feeling: A sleek, twisty set-piece machine that scratched my spy itch.

path_5.title: Gone Girl (2014)
path_5.feeling: Icy, riveting satire of media and marriage that kept me leaning in.

path_5.title: Network (1976)
path_5.feeling: A ferocious media screed that still feels bracingly alive.

path_5.title: Rushmore (1998)
path_5.feeling: Wry, tender early Wes that hits my offbeat sweet spot.

path_5.title: True Romance (1993)
path_5.feeling: Pulp heart and propulsive swagger—messy but irresistible.

path_5.title: Hercules (1997)
path_5.feeling: Zippy, quippy myth romp that entertains without lingering.

path_5.title: Antz (1998)
path_5.feeling: Neurotic charm and sly satire outweigh the dated sheen.

path_5.title: Dirty Grandpa (2016)
path_5.feeling: Raunchy, try-hard gags that wore me down fast.

path_5.title: Iron Man (2008)
path_5.feeling: A clean, crowd-pleasing origin with just enough spark.

path_5.title: Die Hard 2 (1990)
path_5.feeling: Bruising, snowbound sequel fun that can’t match the original’s spark.

path_5.title: Godfather, The (1972)
path_5.feeling: Majestic, bruising crime saga that never loosens its grip.

path_5.title: Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back (2001)
path_5.feeling: Juvenile, amiable road goof that coasts on enough gags.

path_5.title: Fifth Element, The (1997)
path_5.feeling: Gleeful, maximalist space opera whose wild imagination wins out.
